title: Correlative Nanoscopy Using Nano-Optical Imaging and Spectroscopy
content: Scattering-type Scanning Near-field Optical Microscopy (s-SNOM) is a scanning probe technique bypassing the ubiquitous diffraction limit of light to achieve a spatial resolution below 10 nanometer in optical microscopy [1, 2]. s-SNOM employs the strong confinement of light at the apex of a sharp metallic AFM tip to create a nanoscale optical hot-spot. In addition to near-field microscopy the technology has been advanced to enable hyperspectral, nanoscale Fourier-transform spectroscopy (nano-FTIR) using broadband radiation from the visible spectral range, mid-IR and THz spectral ranges, with the particularly useful application in the mid-IR “fingerprint” region due to ability performing material chemical identification with resolution exceeding conventional IR absorption techniques 100-fold.
